question: Question 1 Consider a 2 x 2 square matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} \sigma & x\\ \omega & \sigma \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where x is unknown. If the eigenvalues of the matrix A are [latex](\sigma +j\omega ) \; and \; (\sigma -j\omega )[/latex], then [latex]x[/latex] is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} \sigma & x \\ \omega & \sigma \end{array}\right] \\ \text { Trace } &=\text { sum of eigen values } \\ 2 \sigma &=\sigma+j \omega+\sigma-j \omega \\ |A| &=\text { product of eigens } \\ \sigma^{2}-x \omega &=(\sigma+j \omega)(\sigma-j \omega)=\sigma^{2}+\omega^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] which is possible only when, [latex]x=-\omega[/latex]

question: Question 2 For  [latex]f(z)=\frac{sin(z)}{z^{2}}[/latex], the residue of the pole at z=0 is __________
solution: Residue of [latex]\frac{\sin z}{z^{2}} [/latex] = coefficient of [latex] \frac{1}{2}[/latex] in [latex]\left\{\frac{z-\frac{z^{3}}{3 !}+\frac{z^{5}}{5 !}---}{z^{2}}\right\} [/latex] = coefficient of [latex]\frac{1}{z}[/latex] in [latex]\left\{\frac{1}{z}-\frac{z}{3 !}+\frac{z^{3}}{5 !}---\right\} [/latex] [latex] =1[/latex]

question: Question 3 The probability of getting a "head" in a single toss of a biased coin is 0.3. The coin is tossed repeatedly till a "head" is obtained. If the tosses are independent, then the probability of getting "head" for the first time in the fifth toss is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P(H)&=0.3 \\ P(T)&=0.7 \end{aligned}[/latex] since all tosses are independent so, probability of getting head for the first time in [latex] 5^{\text {th }} [/latex] toss is [latex] \begin{aligned} &=P(T) P(T) P(T) P(T) P(H) \\ &=0.7 \times 0.7 \times 0.7 \times 0.7 \times 0.3=0.072 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 The integral [latex]\int_{0}^{1}\frac{dx}{\sqrt{(1-x)}}[/latex] is equal to __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}} d x &=-2 \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{1-x}} d x \\ &=-\left.2(\sqrt{1-x})\right|_{0} ^{1} \\ &=-2(0-1)=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Consider the first order initial value problem [latex]y'=y+2x-x^{2},y(0)=1,(0\leq x\leq \infty )[/latex] with exact solution [latex]y(x)=x^{2}+e^{x}[/latex]. For x = 0.1, the percentage difference between the exact solution and the solution obtained using a single iteration of the second-order Runge-Kutta method with step-size h = 0.1 is __________
Question 6 Consider the signal [latex]x(t)=cos(6\pi t)+sin(8\pi t)[/latex],  where t is in seconds. The Nyquist sampling rate (in samples/second) for the signal y(t)=x(2t+ 5) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(t) & =\cos (6 \pi t)+\sin (8 \pi t) \\ Y(t) & =x(2 t+5) \\ Y(t) & =\cos [6 \pi(2 t+5)+\sin (8 \pi(2 t+5)] \\ & =\cos (12 \pi t+30 \pi)+\sin (16 \pi t+40 \pi) \\ f_{m_{1}} & =6 \mathrm{Hz}_{i} \qquad f_{m 2}=8 \mathrm{Hz}\\ \text{Nyquist }&\text{sampling rate},\\ f_{s} &=2 f_{\max } \\ &=16 \text { samples/second } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 7 If the signal [latex]x(t)=\frac{sin(t)}{\pi t}*\frac{sin(t)}{\pi t}[/latex] with * denoting the convolution operation, then x(t) is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=x_{1}(t) * x_{1}(t) \\ X(\omega) &=X_{1}(\omega) \cdot X_{1}(\omega) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad x(t)=\frac{\sin t}{\pi t}[/latex]

question: Question 8 A discrete-time signal [latex]x[n]=\delta [n-3]+2\delta [n-5][/latex] has z-transform X(z). If X(z)=X(-z) is the z-transform of another signal y[n], then
Question 9 the RLC circuit shown in the figure, the input voltage is given by [latex]v_{i}(t)=2cos(200t)+4sin(500t)[/latex] The output voltage [latex]v_{0}(t)[/latex] is
solution: Where, [latex]V_{i}(t)=2 \cos (200 t)+4 \sin (500 t)[/latex] As different frequencies are operating, using superposition theorem, we get for [latex]\omega=200 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} x_{L}=\omega L=(200)(0.25)=50 \Omega \\ x_{C}=\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{200 \times 100 \times 10^{-6}}=50 \Omega \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0}(t) &=V_{i}(t) \\ X_{L} &=0.4 \times 500=200 \Omega \\ X_{C} &=\frac{1}{10 \times 10^{-6} \times 500}=200 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad V_{0}(t)&=V_{i}(t) \\ \text { Therefore } \quad V_{0}(t)&=2 \cos (200 t)+4 \sin (500 t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 10 The I-V characteristics of three types of diodes at the room temperature, made of semiconductors X, Y and Z, are shown in the figure. Assume that the diodes are uniformly doped and identical in all respects except their materials. If [latex]E_{gX},E_{gY} \; and \; E_{gZ}[/latex] are the band gaps of X, Y and Z, respectively,
then
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} X \rightarrow \text { Ge Diode } \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots E_{G}=0.2 \mathrm{V} \\ Y \rightarrow \text { Si Diode } \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots E_{G}=0.7 \mathrm{V} \\ Z \rightarrow \text { GaAs Diode }(\text { or }) \mathrm{LED} \ldots \ldots \ldots . E_{G}=1.3 \mathrm{V} \end{array}[/latex]

options.D: no relationship among these band gaps exists.

question: Question 11 The figure shows the band diagram of a Metal Oxide Semiconductor (MOS). The surface region of this MOS is in
solution: Substrate is N-type SC.

question: Question 12 The figure shows the I-V characteristics of a solar cell illuminated uniformly with solar light of power [latex]100 mW/cm^{2}[/latex]. The solar cell has an area of [latex]3cm^{2}[/latex] and a fill factor of 0.7. The maximum efficiency (in %) of the device is __________
solution: Fill factor [latex]=\frac{\text { Maximum obtained power }}{V_{O C} \cdot I_{S C}} [/latex] [latex] 0.7=\frac{\text { Maximum obtained power }}{0.5 \times 180 \times 10^{-3}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Maximum obtained power, [latex]P_{m}=0.063 \mathrm{W} [/latex] Efficiency [latex]\eta=\frac{P_{m}}{G \cdot A}=\frac{0.063}{100 \times 10^{-3} \times 3}=21 \% [/latex] G [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] input light in [latex]\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 13 The diodes D1 and D2 in the figure are ideal and the capacitors are identical. The product RC is very large compared to the time period of the ac voltage. Assuming that the diodes do not breakdown in the reverse bias, the output voltage [latex]V_{0}[/latex] (in volt) at the steady state is __________
solution:
During first positive quarter cycle both diodes  D1 
 and  D2 conduct and at  [latex]t=\frac{T}{4}[/latex] both will be OFF. Both the capacitors will charge to  [latex]10 \mathrm{V}[/latex]  as shown 
is above figure and  [latex]V_{0}=0[/latex]  in steady state.

question: Question 14 Consider the circuit shown in the figure. Assuming [latex]V_{BE1}=V_{EB2}[/latex] = 0.7 volt, the value of the dc voltage [latex]V_{C2}=[/latex] (in volt) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{1}: \quad V_{C B}&=0\\ \text{We know,}\\ V_{C B 1}+V_{B E 1}&=V_{C E 1} \\ \Rightarrow V_{C E 1}&=V_{B E 1}=0.7 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{KVL to loop 1}\\ -2.5+V_{C E 1}&+0.7+I_{B 2} \times 10 \mathrm{K}+1 \mathrm{V}=0 \\ \rightarrow I_{B 2}&=\frac{2.5-1.4-1}{10 K}=0.01 \mathrm{mA} \\ I_{C 2} &=\beta_{2} I_{B 2}=0.5 \mathrm{mA} \\ V_{C 2} &=I_{C 2} \times 1 K=0.5 \times 10^{-3} \times 1 \times 10^{3} \\ &=0.5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 In the astable multivibrator circuit shown in the figure, the frequency of oscillation (in kHz) at the output pin 3 is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} f=\frac{1}{0.69\left(R_{A}+2 R_{B}\right) C} \\ =\frac{1}{0.69\left(2.2 \times 10^{3}+2 \times 4.7 \times 10^{3}\right) \times 0.022 \times 10^{-6}} \\ =5.6818 \mathrm{kHz} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 16 In an 8085 microprocessor, the contents of the accumulator and the carry flag are A7 (in hex) and 0, respectively. If the instruction RLC is executed, then the contents of the accumulator (in hex) and the carry flag, respectively, will be
solution: RLC: Rotate accumulator left by 1 bit without carry Before RLC operation: [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=A 7 H=(10100111)_{2} \\ C Y &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] After RLC operation: [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=(01001111)_{2}=4 \mathrm{FH} \\ \mathrm{CY} &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 The logic functionality realized by the circuit shown below is
solution:
The output Y will be logic 1, when [latex]
 A=1, B=1 [/latex] and  [latex]\bar{B}=0 [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow  Y=A \cdot B \cdot \bar{B}=A \cdot B [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow [/latex] AND operation

question: Question 18 The minimum number of 2-input NAND gates required to implement a 2-input XOR gate is
Question 19 The block diagram of a feedback control system is shown in the figure. The overall closed-loop gain G of the system is

Question 20 For the unity feedback control system shown in the figure, the open-loop transfer function G(s) is given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}[/latex] . The steady state error [latex]e_{ss}[/latex] due to a unit step input is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E(s) &=\frac{R(s)}{1+G(s) H(s)} \\ R(s) &=\frac{1}{s} ; G(s)=\frac{2}{s(s+1)}; \\ H(s) &=1 \\ E(s) &=\frac{\frac{1}{s}}{1+\frac{s}{s(s+1)}}=\frac{s+1}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} s E(s) \\ &=\lim _{s \rightarrow 0} \frac{s(s+1)}{s^{2}+s+2} \\ e_{s s} &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 For a superheterodyne receiver, the intermediate frequency is 15 MHz and the local oscillator frequency is 3.5 GHz. If the frequency of the received signal is greater than the local oscillator frequency, then the image frequency (in MHz) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I F &=15 \mathrm{MHz} \\ f_{l} &=3.5 \mathrm{GHz} \\ f_{\mathrm{si}} &=f_{l}-\mathrm{IF} \\ &=3500-15 \mathrm{MHz}=3485 \mathrm{MHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 An analog baseband signal, bandlimited to 100 Hz, is sampled at the Nyquist rate. The samples are quantized into four message symbols that occur independently with probabilities p1 = p4 = 0.125 and p2 = p3. The information rate (bits/sec) of the message source is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{m} &=100 \mathrm{Hz} \\ f_{s} &=2 f_{m}=200 \text { samplesisec } \\ P_{1} &=P_{4}=\frac{1}{8} \\ P_{1}+P_{2}+P_{3}+P_{4} &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 P_{2}&= 2 P_{3}=1-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{4} \\ P_{2}&= P_{3}=\frac{3}{8} \\ H &=\sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{i} \log \frac{1}{P_{i}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{8} \log _{2} 8+\frac{1}{8} \log _{2} 8&+\frac{3}{8} \log _{2} \frac{8}{3}+\frac{3}{8} \log _{2} \frac{8}{3} \\ H &=1.811 \text { bits/sample }\\ \text{Information rate }\\ R=H(\text { bits/sample }) &\times r(\text { samples/sec }) \\ &=1.811 \times 200 \\ &=362.2 \mathrm{bits} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 A binary baseband digital communication system employs the signal [latex]P(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt{T_{s}}}, & 0\leq t\leq T_{s}\\ 0,& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] for transmission of bits. The graphical representation of the matched filter output y(t) for this signal will be
solution: Impulse response of matched filter, [latex] h(t)=P\left(T_{s}-t\right) [/latex] Output of matched filter, [latex]y(t) = P( t) * h(t)[/latex]

question: Question 24 If a right-handed circularly polarized wave is incident normally on a plane perfect conductor, then the reflected wave will be
solution:
Left circularly polarized, due to direction change
after the reflection from conductor.

options.C: elliptically polarized with a tilt angle of [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 25 Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction is mathematically described by which one of the following equations?
solution: Rate of change of magnetic field results in induced voltage, [latex] \nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t}[/latex]

question: Question 26 The particular solution of the initial value problem given below is [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}+12\frac{dy}{dx}+36y=0[/latex] with [latex]y(0)=3[/latex] and [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}|_{x=0}=-36[/latex]

Question 27 If the vectors [latex]e_{1}=(1,0,2), \; e_{2}=(0,1,0)[/latex] and [latex]e_{3}=(-2,0,1)[/latex] form an orthogonal basis of the three dimensional
real space [latex]\mathbb{R}^{3}[/latex], then the vector [latex]u=(4,3,-3)\in \mathbb{R}^{3}[/latex] can be expressed as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\left[\begin{array}{c}4 \\ 3 \\ -3\end{array}\right] &=a\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0 \\ 2\end{array}\right]+b\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]+c\left[\begin{array}{c}-2 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right] \\ a-2 c &=4 \\ b &=3 \\ 2 a+c &=-3 \\ \text{from here } a &=-\frac{2}{5} \\ b&=3 \\ c&=-\frac{11}{5} \\ u&=-\frac{2}{5} e_{1}+3 e_{2}-\frac{11}{5} e_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 A triangle in the xy-plane is bounded by the straight lines 2x = 3y, y = 0 and x = 3. The volume above the triangle and under the plane x + y + z = 6 is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Volume } &=\iiint d z d x d y=\iint z d y d \\ &=\int_{0}^{32 } \int_{0}^{/ 3 x}(6-x-y) d y d x\\ &=\left.\int_{0}^{3}\left(6 y-x y-\frac{y^{2}}{2}\right)\right|_{0} ^{2 / 3 x} d x \\ &=\int_{0}^{3}\left(4 x-\frac{8}{9} x^{2}\right) d x \\ &=\left.\left[4 \frac{x^{2}}{2}-\frac{8}{9} \cdot \frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{0} ^{3} \\ &=\left.\left[2 x^{2}-\frac{8}{9}\left(\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right]\right|_{0}^{3} \\ &=18-8=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The values of the integral [latex]\frac{1}{2\pi j}\oint_c  \frac{e^{z}}{z-2}dz[/latex] along a closed contour c in anti-clockwise direction for (i) the point [latex]z_{0}[/latex] = 2 inside the contour c, and (ii) the point [latex]z_{0}[/latex] = 2 outside the contour c, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (i) \quad\quad Z_{0}&=2 -lies inside C \\ \text { So, } \text{Res}(z)&=\lim _{z \rightarrow 2}(z-2) \cdot \frac{e^{z}}{z-2} \\ &=e^{2}=7.39 \\ \frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int \frac{e^{z}}{z-2} d z &=2 \pi i \cdot \frac{1}{2 \pi i}(7.39)=7.39 \\ (ii)\quad \quad Z_{0}&=-2\text{ lies out side C then} \\ \text{Res}(z)&=0 \\ \text{So, }\int_{c} \frac{e^{z}}{z-2} d z&=2 \pi i \frac{1}{2 \pi i}(0)=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 A signal [latex]2cos(\frac{2\pi t}{3})-cos(\pi t)[/latex] is the input to an LTI system with the transfer function [latex]H(s)=e^{s}+e^{-s}[/latex]. If [latex]C_{k}[/latex] denotes the [latex]k^{th}[/latex]  coefficient in the exponential Fourier series of the output signal, then [latex]C_{3}[/latex] is equal to
solution: Given. [latex]H(s)=e^{s}+e^{-s} [/latex] [latex] H\left(e^{i \omega}\right)=e^{j \omega}+e^{-j \omega}=2 \cos \omega [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{if}\quad x_{1}(t)&=2 \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{3} t\right) \\ \omega_{b} &=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \\ H\left(\dot{\mu}_{0}\right) &=2 \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)=2\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=-1 \\ y_{1}(t) &=2 \cos \left(\frac{2 \pi}{3} t+180^{\circ}\right) \\ \text{if}\quad x_{2}(t)&=\cos \pi t \\ \omega_{b} &=\pi \\ H\left(e^{i \theta_{0}}\right) &=2 \cos (\pi)=-2 \\ y_{2}(t) &=2 \cos \left(\pi t+180^{\circ}\right) \\ y(t)=2 \cos &\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3} t+\pi\right)-2 \cos (\pi t+\pi) \\ \omega_{1}&=\frac{2 \pi}{3}, \omega_{2}=\pi \\ \omega_{1} &=3 \quad T_{2}=2 \\ \therefore \quad T_{0} &=6 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & 0_{0}=\frac{2 \pi}{T_{0}}=\frac{\pi}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\mathcal{V}(t)=2 \cos \left(2 \omega_{0} t+\pi\right)-2 \cos \left(3 \omega_{0} t+\pi\right)\\ &\mathcal{N}(t)=e^{j(2 \operatorname{cod} t \pi)}+e^{-i\left(2 \omega_{0} \theta^{\prime}+\pi\right)}-e^{j\left(3 \omega_{0} t+\pi\right)}-e^{-i\left(3 \omega_{0} t+\pi\right)}\\ &y(t)=-e^{j\left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)}-e^{-j\left(2 \omega_{0} t\right)}+e^{j\left(3 \omega_{0} t\right)}+e^{-j\left(3 \omega_{0} t\right)}\\ &\therefore \quad C_{3}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The ROC (region of convergence) of the z-transform of a discrete-time signal is represented by the shaded region in the z-plane. If the signal [latex]x[n]=(2.0)^{|n|}[/latex], [latex]-\infty  \lt n \lt +\infty[/latex], then the ROC of its z-transform is represented by
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \begin{aligned} \text { Given, } & x[n]=(2.0)^{\ln 1},-\infty \lt n \lt +\infty \\ &=2^{n}(n]+\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(-n-1) \end{aligned} \\ \text{ROC}:|z| \gt 2 \text { and }|z| \lt \frac{1}{2}\\ \therefore \text{No Roc} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 32 Assume that the circuit in the figure has reached the steady state before time [latex]t= 0[/latex] when the 3 [latex]\Omega[/latex] resistor suddenly burns out, resulting in an open circuit. The current i(t) (in ampere) at [latex]t=0^+[/latex] is__________
solution:
At [latex]t = 0^{-}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
I &=\frac{12}{6}=2 \mathrm{A} \\
V_{3 F} &=10 \times \frac{2}{5}=4 \mathrm{V} \\
V_{2 F} &=10 \times \frac{3}{5}=6 \mathrm{V}
\end{aligned}[/latex] At [latex]t = 0^{+}[/latex] Note : As the current direction is not mentioned 
in the question, thus by reversing the current 
direction 1 A can also be the answer.

question: Question 33 In the figure shown, the current i (in ampere) is __________
solution: Using KCL at [latex] V_{1} [/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{1}}{1}+\frac{V_{1}-8}{1}+\frac{V_{1}-8}{1}+\frac{V_{1}}{1}=0 [/latex] or [latex]V_{1}=4 V [/latex] considering KVL, we get

question: Question 34 The z-parameter matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} z_{11} &z_{12} \\ z_{21}& z_{22} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] for the two-port network shown is
solution: Redrawing the circuit, [latex] \begin{aligned} Z_{11} &=\frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}=3 \| 6=2 \Omega \\ V_{2} &=-3 \times I_{3 \Omega}=-3 \times I_{1} \times \frac{6}{9}=-2 I_{1} \\ \therefore Z_{21} &=\frac{V_{2}}{I_{1}}=-2 \\ \text { Now, } Z_{22} &=\left.\quad \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\right|_{I_{1}=0}=3 \| 6=2 \Omega \\ V_{1} &=-6 \times I_{6 \Omega} \\ &=-6 \times I_{2} \times \frac{3}{9} \\ &=-2 \\ \therefore[Z] &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -2 \\ -2 & 2 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 A continuous-time speech signal [latex]x_{a}(t)[/latex] is sampled at a rate of 8 kHz and the samples are subsequently grouped in blocks, each of size N. The DFT of each block is to be computed in real time using the radix-2 decimation-in-frequency FFT algorithm. If the processor performs all operations sequentially, and takes 20 [latex]\mu[/latex]s for computing each complex multiplication (including multiplications by 1 and -1) and the time required for addition/subtraction is negligible, then the maximum value of N is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{s} &=8000 \text { samples/sec } \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{s} &=\frac{1}{f_{s}}=\frac{1}{8000} \sec \end{aligned}[/latex] Time for each multiplication [latex]=T_{m}=20 \mu \mathrm{sec} [/latex] [latex] T_{m}=20 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{sec}[/latex] suppose block is of size N , then time taken to generate each block [latex]=N \times T_{s}=N \times \frac{1}{8000}.[/latex] No.  of multiplications that can be performed by processor in the time taken for each block [latex] =\frac{N \times T_{s}}{T_{m}} [/latex] No. of multiplications required to compute DFT by Radix - 2 FFT algorithm [latex] =\frac{N}{2} \log _{2} N[/latex] No. of multiplication required by FFT [latex]\leq[/latex] No. of multiplications that can be performed by the processor in the time taken in each block [Reason: real time] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{N}{2} \log _{2} N & \leq \frac{N \times T_{s}}{T_{m}} \\ \log _{2} N & \leq \frac{2 \times \frac{1}{8000}}{20 \times 10^{-6}}=12.5 \\ N & \leq 2^{125} \\ \therefore \quad N & \leq 2^{12}=4096 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 The direct form structure of an FIR (finite impulse response) filter is shown in the figure. The filter can be used to approximate a
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(n] &=5[x[n]-x[n-2]] \\ H(z) &=\frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}=5\left[1-z^{-2}\right] \\ \text{But,}\quad z &=e^{i \omega} \\ H\left(e^{j \omega}\right) &=5\left[1-e^{-j2w}\right]\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega&=0 \left|H\left(e^{j \omega}\right)\right|=0 \\ \omega&=\frac{\pi}{2} \left|H\left(e^{j \omega}\right)\right|=10 \\ \omega&=\pi \left|H\left(e^{j \omega)} \mid=0\right.\right. \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad[/latex] The given one is bandpass filter.

question: Question 37 The injected excess electron concentration profile in the base region of an npn BJT, biased in the active region, is linear, as shown in the figure. If the area of the emitter-base junction is 0.001 [latex]cm^{2},\mu _{n}=800 cm^{2}/(V-s)[/latex] in the base region and depletion layer widths are negligible, then the collector current [latex]I_{C}[/latex] (in mA) at room temperature is __________ (Given: thermal voltage [latex]V_{T}[/latex] = 26 mV at room temperature, electronic charge [latex]q=1.6\times 10^{-19}C[/latex])
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{c} &=A q D_{n} \frac{d n}{d x} \text { where } D_{n}=\mu_{n} V_{T} \\ &=0.001\left(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\right) 800 \times 26 \times 10^{-3}\left[\frac{10^{14}}{0.5 \times 10^{-4}}\right] \\ &=66.56 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{A}=6.656 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 Figures I and II show two MOS capacitors of unit area. The capacitor in Figure I has insulator materials X (of thickness [latex]t_1 = 1[/latex]nm and dielectric constant [latex]\varepsilon _{1}[/latex] = 4) and Y (of thickness [latex]t_2 = 3 [/latex]nm and dielectric constant [latex]\varepsilon _{2}[/latex] = 20). The capacitor in Figure II has only insulator material X of thickness [latex]t_{Eq}[/latex]. If the capacitors are of equal capacitance, then the value of [latex]t_{Eq}[/latex] (in nm) is __________
solution: From the figure I. Both the capacitors [latex]C_{1}[/latex] and [latex]C_{2}[/latex] are in series Total Capacitance, [latex]C=\frac{C_{1} C_{2}}{C_{1}+C_{2}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} C=& \frac{A e_{1}}{A_{1}} \cdot \frac{A \varepsilon_{2}}{t_{2}} \\ =& \frac{A x_{1}+A \varepsilon_{2}}{t_{1}}+\frac{A \times 20}{12} \\ =& \frac{10^{-9} \cdot \frac{A \times 10^{-9}}{4 \times 4}+\frac{A \times 20}{3 \times 10^{-9}}}{10^{-9}} \\ C=& 2.5 \times 10^{9} \times A \end{aligned}[/latex] From figure II [latex] C=\frac{\varepsilon A}{t_{\theta q}}[/latex] since both capacitors must be equal in figures I  and II [latex] \begin{array}{r} 2.5 \times 10^{9} \times A=\frac{A \times 4}{t_{e q}} \\ t_{e q}=1.6 \mathrm{nm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The I-V characteristics of the zener diodes D1 and D2 are shown in Figure I. These diodes are used in the circuit given in Figure II. If the supply voltage is varied from 0 to 100 V, then breakdown occurs in

Question 40 For the circuit shown in the figure, [latex]R_{1}=R_{2}=R_{3}=1 \Omega , L=1 \mu H[/latex] and [latex]C=1 \mu F[/latex]. If the input [latex]V_{in}=cos(10^{6}t)[/latex], then the overall voltage gain ([latex]V_{out}/V_{in}[/latex]) of the circuit is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H_{1}(s) &=\frac{V_{01}}{V_{i}}=1+\frac{R_{1}}{s L} \\ &=1+\frac{1}{\frac{s L}{R_{1}}}=1+\frac{1}{s \times 10^{-6}} \\ H_{2}(s) &=\frac{V_{0}}{V_{01}}=-\frac{R_{3}}{\frac{R_{2} C s+1}{C s}} \\ &=\frac{-s R_{3} C}{1+s R_{2} C} \\ &=\frac{-C s}{1+C s}=\frac{-1}{1+\frac{1}{C s}} \\ H(s) &=H_{1}(s) H_{2}(s) \\ &=\left(1+\frac{1}{s \times 10^{-6}}\right)\left(\frac{-s \times 1 \times 10^{-6}}{1+s \times 10^{-6}}\right)\\ &=-1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 In the circuit shown in the figure, the channel length modulation of all transistors is non-zero ([latex]\lambda \neq[/latex]0). Also, all transistors operate in saturation and have negligible body effect. The ac small signal voltage gain ([latex]V_{o}/V_{in}[/latex]) of the circuit is
solution: Node equation at [latex] P_{1} [/latex] [latex] g_{m 1} V_{g s 1}+\frac{V_{0}}{r_{01}}+\frac{V_{0}}{r_{03}}+\frac{V_{0}}{r_{02}}-g_{m_{2}} V_{g s_{2}}=0 [/latex] [latex] V_{0}\left(\frac{1}{r_{01}}+\frac{1}{r_{02}}+g_{m 2}+\frac{1}{r_{03}}\right)=-g_{m 1} V_{i n} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow A_{v}=\frac{V_{0}}{V_{\text {in }}}=-g_{m 1}\left[r_{01}\left\|\left[r_{02} \| \frac{1}{g_{m 2}}\right]\right\| r_{03}\right][/latex]

question: Question 42 In the circuit shown in the figure, transistor M1 is in saturation and has transconductance [latex]g_{m}[/latex] = 0.01 siemens. Ignoring internal parasitic capacitances and assuming the channel length modulation [latex]\lambda[/latex]  to be zero, the small signal input pole frequency (in kHz) is __________
solution: With respect to AC Taking miller's equivalent and assume [latex]r_{0}=\propto[/latex] [latex] A_{V}=-g_{m} R_{D}=-0.01 \times 10^{3}=-10 [/latex] small signal input pole frequency [latex] =\frac{1}{2 \pi \times 5 \times 10^{3} \times 50 \times 10^{-12}(1+10)} [/latex] [latex] =57.87 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex]

question: Question 43 Following is the K-map of a Boolean function of five variables P, Q, R, S and X. The minimum sum-of-product (SOP) expression for the function is
solution: [latex]\therefore[/latex] minimum sum of product expression of the function is [latex] =\bar{Q}S\bar{X}+Q\bar{S}X[/latex]

question: Question 44 For the circuit shown in the figure, the delays of NOR gates, multiplexers and inverters are 2 ns, 1.5 ns and 1 ns, respectively. If all the inputs P, Q, R, S and T are applied at the same time instant, the maximum propagation delay (in ns) of the circuit is __________
solution: When, [latex]T=\text{logic} 0[/latex], the path followed by the circuit would be, NOR gate [latex]\rightarrow \text{MUX} 1 \rightarrow \text{MUX} 2 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 2 \mathrm{ns} \rightarrow 1.5 \mathrm{ns} \rightarrow 1.5 \mathrm{ns} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 5 \mathrm{ns} [/latex] When, [latex]T=\text{logic} 1[/latex], the path followed by the circuit would be, NOR gate [latex]\rightarrow MUX 1 \rightarrow NOR gate \rightarrow MUX 2 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 1 \mathrm{ns} \rightarrow 1.5 \mathrm{ns} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{ns} \rightarrow 1.5 \mathrm{ns} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow 6 \mathrm{ns} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex] Maximum propagation delay is 6 ns

question: Question 45 For the circuit shown in the figure, the delay of the bubbled NAND gate is 2 ns and that of the counter is assumed to be zero. If the clock (Clk) frequency is 1 GHz, then the counter behaves as a
solution:
Clock frequency= 1 GHz [latex]\Rightarrow [/latex] Clock time period = 1 ns If the propagation delay of the NANO gate were 
0 ns, the circuit would have behaved as MOD 6 
counter. However, the delay of NANO gate is 2 ns. During 
this time, two more clock pulses would reach the 
counter, and therefore it would count two more 
states. Hence, it acts as MOD 8 counter.

question: Question 46 The first two rows in the Routh table for the characteristic equation of a certain closed-loop control system are given as The range of K for which the system is stable is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c|cc} s^{3}& 1 & (2 k+3) \\ s^{2}&2 k & 4 \\ s&\frac{4 k^{2}+6 k-4}{2 k} & 0\\ s^{0}&4 \end{array}[/latex] For stability, [latex]K \gt 0[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 4 K^{2}+6 K-4& \gt 0 \\ 2 K^{2}+3 K-2& \gt 0 \\ (2 K-1)(K+2)& \gt 0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K& \gt \frac{1}{2} or, k \lt -2 \\ \text{Hence, }\quad 0.5& \lt K \lt \infty \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A second-order linear time-invariant system is described by the following state equations [latex]\frac{d}{dt}x_{1}(t)+2x_{1}(t)=3u(t) [/latex] [latex]\frac{d}{dt}x_{2}(t)+x_{2}(t)=u(t)[/latex] where [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \;  x_{2}(t)[/latex] are the two state variables and u(t) denotes the input. If the output c(t) = [latex]x_{1}(t)[/latex], then the system is

Question 48 The forward-path transfer function and the feedback-path transfer function of a single loop negative feedback control system are given as [latex]G(s)=\frac{K(s+2)}{s^{2}+2s+2}[/latex] and H(s)=1, respectively. If the variable parameter K is real positive, then the location of the breakaway point on
the root locus diagram of the system is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) &=\frac{K(s+2)}{s^{2}+2 s+2} \\ H(s)&=1 \\ 1+G(s) H(s) &=0 \\ 1+\frac{K}{\left(s^{2}\right)+2 s+2}(s+2) &=0\\ K&=-\frac{\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)}{(s+2)} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \frac{d K}{d s}=-\left(\frac{(2 s+2)(s+2)-\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)}{(s+2)^{2}}\right) [/latex] For break away points, [latex] \frac{d K}{d s}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} (2 s+2)(s+2)-\left(s^{2}+2 s+2\right)=0 \\ 2 s^{2}+6 s+4-s^{2}-2 s-2=0 \\ s^{2}+4 s+2=0 \end{array} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} s&=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{16-8}}{2} \\ &=\frac{-4 \pm 2 \sqrt{2}}{2}=-2 \pm \sqrt{2} \\ s&=-0.58 ; s=-3.41 \\ \text{But,}\quad s&=-3.41 \text{ lies on root locus }\\ \text{Hence}\quad s&=-3.41 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A wide sense stationary random process X(t) passes through the LTI system shown in the figure. If the autocorrelation function of X(t) is [latex]R_X(\tau)[/latex], then the autocorrelation function [latex]R_Y(\tau)[/latex] of the output Y(t) is equal to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(t)&=X(t)-\left(t-T_{0}\right) \\ R_{N}(\tau)&=E[Y(t+\tau) Y(t)] \\ &=E[(X(t+\tau)-X(t+\tau-T_{0}))(X(t)-X(t-T_{0}))] \\ &=E[X(t+\tau) X(t)-X(t) X(t+\tau-T_{0}) \\ &-X(t+\tau) X(t-T_{0})  +X(t+\tau-T_{0}) X(t-T_{0})] \end{aligned}[/latex] since, X(t) is a WSS process, [latex] R_{Y}(\tau)=R_{X}(\tau)-R_{X}\left(\tau-T_{0}\right)-R_{X}\left(\tau+T_{0}\right)+R_{X}(\tau) [/latex] [latex] =2 R_{X}(\tau)-R_{X}\left(\tau-T_{0}\right)-R_{X}\left(\tau+T_{0}\right)[/latex]

question:
Question 50 A voice-grade AWGN (additive white Gaussian noise) telephone channel has a bandwidth of 4.0 kHz and two-sided noise power spectral density [latex]\frac{\eta }{2}=2.5 \times 10^{-5}[/latex] Watt per Hz. If information at
the rate of 52 kbps is to be transmitted over this channel with arbitrarily small bit error rate, then the minimum bit-energy [latex]E_{b}[/latex] (in mJ/bit) necessary is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} C=B \log _{2}\left(1+\frac{S}{N}\right) \\ S=E_{b} \cdot R_{b}\\ \left(E_{b}=\text { bit energy, } R_{b}= \text{ information rate bits/sec}\right)\\ C=B \log _{2}\left(1+\frac{E_{D} R_{D}}{N_{o}}\right) \end{array}[/latex] For distortionless transmission, C should be atleast of [latex]R_{b} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \stackrel{R_{b}}{B}&=\log _{2}\left(1+\frac{E_{b} R_{b}}{N_{o} B}\right)\\ E_{b} &=\left(2^{R_{b} / B}-1\right) \frac{N_{0} B}{R_{b}} \\ &=\frac{\left(2^{52 / 13}-1\right) \times 2 \times 2.5 \times 10^{-5} \times 4}{52} \\ E_{p} &=31.504 \mathrm{mJ} / \mathrm{bil} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The bit error probability of a memoryless binary symmetric channel is [latex]10^{-5}[/latex]. If [latex]10^{5}[/latex] bits are sent over this channel, then the probability that not more than one bit will be in error is __________
solution: bit error probability, [latex]p=10^{-5} [/latex] Number of bits transmitted, [latex] n=10^{5}[/latex] If n-bits are transmitted, probability of getting error in 'r' bits is given by [latex] p_{e}={ }^{n} C_{r} \rho^{r}(1-p)^{n-r}[/latex] The probability that not more than one bit will be in error is [latex] \begin{array}{l} ={ }^{n} C_{0} p^{0}(1-p)^{-0}+{ }^{n} C_{\{(p)}^{1}(1-p)^{p-1} \\ =(1-p)^{n}+n p(1-p)^{n-1} \\ =\left(1-10^{-5}\right)^{10^{5}}+10^{5} \times 10^{-5}\left(1-10^{-5}\right)^{10^{5}-1} \\ =0.7357 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 52 Consider an air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions a = 2.286 cm and b = 1.016 cm. At 10 GHz operating frequency, the value of the propagation constant (per meter) of the corresponding propagating mode is __________
solution: Operation frequency [latex]=10 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex] Cut off frequency for [latex]\mathrm{TE}_{10}, \mathrm{f}_{c}=\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2 \mathrm{a}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c} &=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{2 \times 2.286 \times 10^{-2}} \\ &=6.57 \mathrm{GHz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Next mode [latex]T E_{20}[/latex] has [latex]f_{c}=13 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] [latex] 10 \mathrm{GHz} [/latex] operates only in dominant mode. [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{m \pi}{a}\right)^{2}-\omega^{2} \mu \epsilon} \\ &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\pi}{a}\right)^{2}-\frac{(2 \pi f)^{2}}{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}} \\ &=\pi \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{2.286 \times 10^{-2}}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{2 \times 10 \times 10^{9}}{3 \times 10^{8}}\right)^{2}} \\ &=j 158\left(\mathrm{m}^{-1}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Consider an air-filled rectangular waveguide with dimensions a = 2.286 cm and b = 1.016 cm. The increasing order of the cut-off frequencies for different modes is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} a &=2.286 \mathrm{cm} \\ b &=1.016 \mathrm{cm} \\ f_{c_{T E_{10}}} &=\frac{c}{2 a} \\ f_{c_{T E_{01}}} &=\frac{c}{2 b} \\ f_{c_{T E_{20}}} &=\frac{c}{a} \\ f_{c_{T E_{11}}} &=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{b}\right)^{2}} \\ \text{As }a \gt 2 b \Rightarrow f_{c_{T E_{10}}} & \lt f_{c_{T E_{20}}} \lt f_{c_{T E_{01}}} \lt f_{c_{T E_{11}}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A radar operating at 5 GHz uses a common antenna for transmission and reception. The antenna has a gain of 150 and is aligned for maximum directional radiation and reception to a target 1 km away having radar cross-section of 3 [latex]m^{2}[/latex]. If it transmits 100 kW, then the received power (in [latex]\mu[/latex]W) is__________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f&=5 \mathrm{GHz}, G=150, R=1 \mathrm{km} \\ P_{t}&=100 \mathrm{kW}, \sigma=3 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ P_{r}&= \frac{(G \lambda)^{2} \cdot \sigma}{(4 \pi)^{3} R^{4}} \times P_{t} \\ &=\frac{\left(150 \times \frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{5 \times 10^{9}}\right)^{2} \cdot 3}{(4 \pi)^{3} \cdot 10^{12}} \times 10^{5} \\ &=\frac{81 \times 3 \times 10^{5}}{(4 \pi)^{3} \times 10^{12}} \\ &= 1.224 \times 10^{-8}=0.012 \mu \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 Consider the charge profile shown in the figure. The resultant potential distribution is best described by
solution: Applying Poisson's equations [latex] \nabla^{2} V=\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}=-\frac{\rho_{v}}{\epsilon}=K[/latex] Constant charge density [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} &=-K x+K^{\prime} \\ V &=\frac{-K x^{2}}{2}+K^{\prime} x+K^{\prime} \end{aligned}[/latex] Towards positive x or negative side. It is a second order parabolic increase. Due to symmetry of + and - charges K" = 0 is expected with V = O at centre and graph passing through origin. Beyond [latex]x \gt 0 \text{ or } x \lt  b, \; E = 0[/latex] due to capacitive nature of + and - charges [latex] V=-\int 0 \cdot \overrightarrow{d l}=\text { Constant }[/latex] This  constant is same V at x=a or x=b
